idioms.expression: Put my money where my mouth is

idioms.meaning_en: To prove your words by taking real action.

idioms.origin_en: American English, 20th century. Comes from gambling and betting â€” if you believed something strongly, you literally placed money to prove it.
idioms.origin_es: InglÃ©s estadounidense del siglo XX, del mundo de apuestas: si realmente creÃ­as en algo, apostabas dinero.
examples: If you believe in the project, put your money where your mouth is.

idioms.meaning_en: To stay firm in your decision even under pressure.
idioms.meaning_es: Mantenerse firme en tu decisiÃ³n aunque haya presiÃ³n.
idioms.origin_en: Comes from military warfare: soldiers had to stay at their cannons during attacks.
idioms.origin_es: Viene del lenguaje militar: los soldados debÃ­an permanecer en sus caÃ±ones sin rendirse.
examples: Even if they disagree, stick to your guns.

idioms.meaning_en: A competitor expected to lose, but who fights with determination.
idioms.meaning_es: Competidor que se espera que pierda, pero lucha con determinaciÃ³n.
idioms.origin_en: Comes from 19th-century dogfighting. The dog underneath was considered weaker â€” the 'underdog'.
idioms.origin_es: Proviene de peleas de perros del siglo XIX. El perro de abajo era visto como el dÃ©bil: el 'underdog'.
examples: People love cheering for the underdog.

idioms.meaning_en: Used to encourage someone to continue speaking or acting.
idioms.meaning_es: Usado para animar a alguien a continuar hablando o actuando.
idioms.origin_en: General phrasal verb from Old English 'gÄn' (to go).
idioms.origin_es: Verbo compuesto del inglÃ©s antiguo 'gÄn' (ir).
examples: Go on, tell me the rest.

idioms.meaning_en: To leave or disappear.
idioms.meaning_es: Irse o desaparecer.
idioms.origin_en: Literal Old English concept â€” to move away.
idioms.origin_es: Significado literal: alejarse.
examples: Go away, Iâ€™m tired.

idioms.meaning_en: To record something on paper or a device.
idioms.meaning_es: Anotar algo en papel o dispositivo.
idioms.origin_en: From the verb 'write' + particle 'down' meaning to capture and store information.
idioms.origin_es: Del verbo 'write' + 'down', usado para capturar informaciÃ³n.
examples: Write it down so you donâ€™t forget.

idioms.meaning_en: Handle whatever remains to be done.
idioms.meaning_es: Encargarse de lo que falta por hacer.

idioms.meaning_en: In slang, 'bad' means excellent or impressive.
idioms.meaning_es: En slang, 'bad' significa excelente o impresionante.
idioms.origin_en: African American Vernacular English (AAVE), 1970s music culture.
idioms.origin_es: Del AAVE, cultura musical de los 70.
examples: That car is bad! ğŸ˜ğŸ”¥

idioms.meaning_en: Informal contraction for am not / is not / are not.
idioms.meaning_es: ContracciÃ³n informal de am not / is not / are not.
idioms.origin_en: Originated as 'an't' in the 1700s.
idioms.origin_es: OriginÃ³ como 'an't' en los 1700s.
examples: He ain't ready.

idioms.meaning_en: It's not surprising; it makes sense.
idioms.meaning_es: No es de extraÃ±ar.
idioms.origin_en: From combining 'no' + 'wonder' (surprise), indicating lack of surprise.
idioms.origin_es: De combinar 'no' + 'wonder' (sorpresa), indicando falta de sorpresa.
examples: No wonder you're tiredâ€”you worked all night!

idioms.meaning_en: A question suggesting uncertainty or a possible explanation.
idioms.meaning_es: Â¿PodrÃ­a ser el viento?
idioms.origin_en: Literal question using modal 'could' for speculation.
idioms.origin_es: Pregunta literal usando modal 'could' para especulaciÃ³n.
examples: I heard a strange noise. Could it be the wind?

idioms.meaning_en: The act of finishing or concluding something.
idioms.meaning_es: Finalizando, concluyendo
idioms.origin_en: From wrapping a package, metaphorically completing a task.
idioms.origin_es: De envolver un paquete, metafÃ³ricamente completar una tarea.
examples: Let's start wrapping up the meeting.

idioms.meaning_en: A thorough and detailed examination or analysis of something.
idioms.meaning_es: AnÃ¡lisis profundo, mirada detallada
idioms.origin_en: From 'in depth' (thoroughly) + 'look' (examination).
idioms.origin_es: De 'in depth' (profundamente) + 'look' (examen).
examples: The article provides an in-depth look at climate change.

The documentary gives an in-depth look into ancient civilizations.

idioms.meaning_en: A phrase used to indicate maximizing something or getting the greatest benefit.
idioms.meaning_es: Sacar el mÃ¡ximo provecho, aprovechar al mÃ¡ximo
idioms.origin_en: From 'most' (maximum) + 'out' (extracted).
idioms.origin_es: De 'most' (mÃ¡ximo) + 'out' (extraÃ­do).
examples: She tries to get the most out of her workday.

idioms.meaning_en: Sharp or acute attention to detail.
idioms.meaning_es: ObservaciÃ³n aguda
idioms.origin_en: From 'keen' (sharp) + 'observation' (watching carefully).
idioms.origin_es: De 'keen' (agudo) + 'observation' (observaciÃ³n cuidadosa).
examples: Her keen observation helped solve the case.

idioms.meaning_en: Refers to something lacking originality or creativity.
idioms.meaning_es: Molde de galletas, genÃ©rico, uniforme
idioms.origin_en: From a tool used to cut cookies into identical shapes, suggesting uniformity.
idioms.origin_es: De una herramienta usada para cortar galletas en formas idÃ©nticas, sugiriendo uniformidad.
examples: The neighborhood is full of cookie-cutter houses.

Use the cookie cutter to make star-shaped cookies.

idioms.meaning_en: To participate, attract, or involve someone in something.
idioms.meaning_es: Participar, involucrar, atraer
idioms.origin_en: From Old French 'engagier', meaning 'to pledge'.
idioms.origin_es: Del francÃ©s antiguo 'engagier', que significa 'comprometer'.
examples: She engages with her community by volunteering.

idioms.meaning_en: Small parts of something.
idioms.meaning_es: Pedazos, partes
idioms.origin_en: From 'bits' (small pieces) + 'pieces' (fragments), emphasizing smallness.
idioms.origin_es: De 'bits' (pedazos pequeÃ±os) + 'pieces' (fragmentos), enfatizando pequeÃ±ez.
examples: I gathered the bits and pieces of the puzzle.

idioms.meaning_en: You are crazy or irrational.
idioms.meaning_es: EstÃ¡s loco
idioms.origin_en: From slang use of 'nuts' meaning crazy, possibly from 'off one's nut' (head).
idioms.origin_es: Del uso del slang 'nuts' significando loco, posiblemente de 'off one's nut' (cabeza).
examples: You are nuts if you think that will work!

idioms.meaning_en: Used to emphasize a negative statement or question; in any way or to any degree
idioms.meaning_es: En absoluto, para nada; de ninguna manera
idioms.origin_en: From Middle English 'at alle', meaning 'in any way' or 'wholly'.
idioms.origin_es: Del inglÃ©s medio 'at alle', que significa 'de ninguna manera' o 'completamente'.
examples: I don't like it at all.
Do you speak French at all?
She's not tired at all.
Is there any hope at all?
I can't see anything at all.
Not at all! (You're welcome / It's no problem)

idioms.meaning_en: Being in a group makes you safer or more protected than being alone
idioms.meaning_es: Estar en grupo te hace mÃ¡s seguro o protegido que estar solo
idioms.origin_en: Ancient concept dating back to survival instincts. Animals and humans historically traveled in groups for protection from predators and threats. The phrase became popular in English in the 19th century.
idioms.origin_es: Concepto antiguo que se remonta a los instintos de supervivencia. Animales y humanos histÃ³ricamente viajaban en grupos para protegerse de depredadores y amenazas. La frase se popularizÃ³ en inglÃ©s en el siglo XIX.
examples: Let's all walk home togetherâ€”there's safety in numbers.
The protesters believe there's safety in numbers.
In the wild, many animals travel in herds because of safety in numbers.
Don't go alone at night; there's safety in numbers.
